block.p: Rice and Hawks in Debate Over Iran, Officials Say A behind-the-scenes debate has pitted Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and her deputies against the Bush administration's few remaining hawks over whether the state department strategy has any hope of reining in Iran's nuclear program, according to officials.

Deferral of Palestine Statehood With the violence in Gaza City largely over, people worried not only about daily survival but also about how the round of deadly infighting, which killed a reported 116 people, postponed hope for an independent and unified Palestinian state.
Dozens of armed and uniformed members of the various security forces loyal to the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, gathered in Ramallah's central Manara Square in a show of force.
The European Union extended firm support to Mr. Abbas and said it would continue aid to the Palestinian territories despite Hamas's seizure of control in Gaza.
Sunni Mosque Bombed in Iraq The bombing of a Sunni Arab mosque near Basra appeared to signal that the cycle of reprisals after the bombing of a Shiite shrine in Samarra had not entirely ended.

Labor Abuse Scandal in China Stories have been sweeping through China, putting real faces on a scandal involving the kidnapping of hundreds of children then forced to work in brutal conditions in brick kilns.
Prosecutor in Duke Case Announces Resignation

District Attorney Michael B. Nifong of Durham County, N.C., announced his resignation as he faces disciplinary charges for his handling of a sexual assault prosecution against three former Duke University lacrosse players.

Drought Brings Out the Snakes While the snake-wrangling business in Los Angeles is often bustling in the spring, when snakes come out to mate, business is especially booming this year because of a drought.

House Approves Security Bill The House approved spending of $37.4 billion next year by the Department of Homeland Security, calling for more spending than proposed by the Bush administration, including hundreds of millions in extra state and antiterrorism grants.

Acknowledging that the nation remains too vulnerable to terrorist attack by small planes and recreational boats, the Department of Homeland Security is considering new requirements to allow authorities to identify operators and passengers in millions of these vehicles as they ply the coasts and skies.

More Schools Use Mindfulness Mindfulness, a stress-reducing technique, while common in hospitals, corporations, professional sports and even prisons, is relatively new in the education of squirming children. But a small but growing number of schools are slowly embracing the concept.

At City Hall, Journalist Operates in a Form of Exile As an independent publisher, Rafael Martínez Alequin has tormented generations of politicians with pointed questions. But it took Mayor Bloomberg to actually bar him from City Hall news conferences, and even though he's been allowed back, he operates in a kind of exile. B1

Harlem Store Fights Eviction Though 125th Street has been transformed by chain stores, Sikhulu Shange's Record Shack has remained an unofficial landmark for 35 years. Now, Mr. Shange once again faces eviction. B3
Mortgage Fraud Goes Online Web sites that deceive lenders by making insolvent home shoppers look more attractive have fueled an increase in mortgage fraud.

Gas, Food Costs Up Again Higher food and energy prices pushed the consumer price index up 0.7 percent in May. Average weekly earnings for most fell for the second straight month, and consumer confidence dropped to its lowest level in 10 months.
Editorials: The scarlet letter; prescription for pain; slashing and warming; adult-only Froot Loops.
Columns: Bob Herbert and Timothy Egan.
